notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon to wife of Girard Franceon (pregnant)
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle luy souhaitoit n'avoir jamais bien joye, ny contantement du fruict qu'elle portoit en son ventre, jusques a ce qu'elle auroit dict la verité
notable_quotes.english: that she wished her never to have any joy or contentment from the fruit she carried in her belly, until she told the truth

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon to Curien de Champ
notable_quotes.french: qu'il avoit des chevaulx qu'ilz alloient pasturer en grabix, mais qu'ilz n'y yroient plus
notable_quotes.english: that he had horses that went to pasture in grabix, but they would not go there anymore
notable_quotes.context: After he killed one of her geese

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon to servant of Claudon Colas Colin
notable_quotes.french: Toy, et ton maitre se repentiront de ce que tu faict
notable_quotes.english: You and your master will repent of what you have done
notable_quotes.context: After servant chased away her geese

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon to Mengeon Bandesapt
notable_quotes.french: que le diable luy puisse rompre le col
notable_quotes.english: may the devil break its neck
notable_quotes.context: About his horse that broke fence and got into her barley field

notable_quotes.speaker: Jean de Sombois to Jennon
notable_quotes.french: il feroit ung mauvais coup sur elle
notable_quotes.english: he would do something bad to her
notable_quotes.context: Accused her of giving him trouble with his finger, threatened her to heal it

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon's son Franceon (reported by Nicolas Marquis)
notable_quotes.french: et qu'il n'y avoit point de bonne fiance... affin qu'elle soit maistresse, et qu'elle jouysse du bien, et qu'elle estoit d'ung tres mauvais courage
notable_quotes.english: and that there was no good faith in it... so that she could be mistress and enjoy the goods, and that she was of a very bad disposition
notable_quotes.context: Speaking about his mother having been accused of witchcraft and his father being normally ill

economic_context.details: Multiple disputes over property boundaries, animal trespass, and garden access. Nicolas Haxo lent accused's husband 100 francs; when he asked for security a year later was refused and fell ill. Accused's husband had stolen fish from pond and been fined. Witness #7 (weaver) had dispute over speed of completing work. Many disputes centered on agricultural damage by animals.

material_culture.context: Multiple disputes involving accused's geese eating in neighbors' fields and meadows
Curien de Champ killed one of her geese with his fork
Accused said she had quarrelled with Mongeotte over some verjus
Jean de Sombois (weaver) had not woven some cloth for her as quickly as she wanted
Nicolas Haxo lent 100 francs to husband of accused
Nicolas Haxo saw 2 civieres behind her house and asked for one as interest on loan
Devil gave her black powder to kill people and animals
Devil gave her grey powder to kill people and animals
Devil gave her money which turned into leaves
Gave master a white hen around St Martin each year to be excused attendance at sabbat
Her field was sown with barley when horse broke fence

extraction_metadata.notes: Complete trial record with extensive witness testimony. Trial began with reference to 1614 accusation by Mongeatte of Pajaille. Multiple disputes over geese damaging crops/meadows, and boundary/trespass issues. Accused was about 50, married 32 years, and was lame (mentioned as reason for limited sabbat attendance). She resisted torture (thumbscrews and rack) but confessed when threatened with tortillons. Her confession was somewhat inconsistent (judges questioned timeline of seduction vs. malefices committed earlier). Notable that her own son suggested she might be harming his father. Economic status assessed as poor based on: husband had stolen fish and been fined, debt dispute over 100 francs, multiple conflicts over animal trespass suggesting small-scale agriculture, no mention of property ownership beyond fields. No evidence of healing practices mentioned. Change de Nancy approved both torture and death sentence without modification. Execution location (St Dié) differed from interrogation location (Abbey of Etival).
